articles.title: Curriculum Vitae
articles.contents: You can find my CV here.

articles.title: Dissemination
articles.contents:
Expert Advisory
Member of expert network, Transparency International
Denmark
In May 2021, I was invited to join Transparency International
Denmark’s network of Danish researchers who have expertise related to
corruption and abuse of power. Description in Danish here.

Oral dissemination of
research
Research presentation, Transparency International
Denmark, May 2021
Presentation about my research field for the board of Transparency
International Denmark. Further, I provided my inputs and discussed how
to mitigate corruption and malfeasance in the Danish municipalities in
relation to the (at that point) upcoming Danish municipal election in
November 2021.
Research presentation at Projekt Forskerspirer,
April 2021
Presentation about my research and reseach designs broadly for the
social science section in Projekt Forskerspirer (Junior Researchers
Project) – a program where academically talented high school students
conduct their own research.

Dissemination of research in
media
DR P1 Orientering, June 14, 2022
Radio interview about politicians’ careers, working conditions and
party switching in the news program Orientering on P1 – a nationwide
Danish radio station.
Politiken, June 29, 2021: ”Pia overbeviser ligeså godt som
Per, når hun udtaler sig som ekspert” with Katrine
Greve-Poulsen, Rasmus Tue Pedersen and Erik Albæk.
Article disseminating the results of our research article ”No Gender
Bias in Audience Perceptions of Male and Female Experts in the News:
Equally Competent and Persuasive” in the Danish newspaper
Politiken.
Danish URL here
Uniavisen/The University Post, June 25, 2021: ”New study:
Readers perceive male and female experts as equally
competent”.
My co-author Katrine Greve-Poulsen and I were interviewed about our
first academic publication by University of Copenhagen’s independent
news paper Uniavisen (The University Post).
English version here,
Danish version here.

            Welcome to my website and thanks for stopping by!
            I am a PhD Candidate at Department of
            Political Science, University of Copenhagen. During my
            PhD, I have been Visiting Researcher at Department
            of International Economics, Government and Business,
            Copenhagen Business School and Department of Government,
            Harvard University.
            My research revolve around politicians’ private benefits
            and downsides of serving in office and how this affect the
            political system and the composition of the political class,
            i.e. its’ quality and scope of representation. I study this
            in Denmark and am delighted to work with rich registry data
            from the Danish authorities. I deploy various types of
            quasi-experiments and traditional experiments to derive
            credible conclusions about the realm of politics.
            My PhD is supervised by Professor Lene
            Holm Pedersen and Assistant Professor Jens Olav Dahlgaard and
            Professor James
            Snyder was my sponsor at Harvard.

              Welcome to my website and thanks for stopping by!
              I am a PhD Candidate at Department of
              Political Science, University of Copenhagen. During my
              PhD, I have been Visiting Researcher at Department
              of International Economics, Government and Business,
              Copenhagen Business School and Department of Government,
              Harvard University.
              My research revolve around politicians’ private
              benefits and downsides of serving in office and how this
              affect the political system and the composition of the
              political class, i.e. its’ quality and scope of
              representation. I study this in Denmark and am delighted
              to work with rich registry data from the Danish
              authorities. I deploy various types of quasi-experiments
              and traditional experiments to derive credible conclusions
              about the realm of politics.
              My PhD is supervised by Professor Lene
              Holm Pedersen and Assistant Professor Jens Olav Dahlgaard
              and Professor James
              Snyder was my sponsor at Harvard.

articles.title: Research
articles.contents:
Here you can see my research – published articles (yeah alright,
there is only one for now) as well as stuff I am currently working
on.
If you want a copy of one of my working papers please reach out to me
at fkl [at] ifs.ku.dk.
Published work
Greve-Poulsen, K., Larsen, F. K., Pedersen, R. T.,
& Albæk, E. (2021). No Gender Bias in Audience Perceptions
of Male and Female Experts in the News: Equally Competent and
Persuasive. The International Journal of
Press/Politics, OnlineFirst.
Open
Access version
Code and replication data

Work in progress
Reward or Punishment? The Distribution of Life-Cycle Returns
to Political Office with Jens Olav Dahlgaard and Nicolai
Kristensen. Under review. Working paper version here
We estimate the economic returns to winning office focusing on close
winning and losing candidates running for Danish national elections. We
devote special attention to 1) effect heterogeneity among candidates
with different pre-office income potentials and 2) the timing of returns
to office, as some economic consequences of holding office occur
immediately when entering office while others occur later in life.

When the Going Gets Tough, the Tough Gets Going – Victims of
Sexism and Harassment in the Candidate Pool State Stronger Preferences
for Political Influence with Lene Holm Pedersen. Under
review.
We investigate political candidates’ preferences for different job
attributes of holding office using a conjoint-choice experiment fielded
among the political candidates in the Danish municipal election in
November 2021.

Government Ideology and Gender Equality in Public Sector
Promotions with Lasse Aaskoven and Benjamin Egerod. Under
review.
Relying on granular data of the universe of Danish civil servants,
we estimate how women’s career progression in the Danish bureaucracy
depend on the ideology of the government in office.

The Electoral Rewards From Improved Representation of
Women with Jens Olav Dahlgaard, Benjamin Egerod and Lene Holm
Pedersen.
We investigate if the election of a woman for office foster female
representation in future elections and beyond the candidate herself. We
do this by focusing on local elections, where a woman marginally wins a
seat over a man competing for the same seat, and estimate what this
means to the composition of the future candidate pools and thus how it
shapes the supply of political candidates.

Amateurs in Office: Monetary and Job Market Returns to
Part-Time Office Holding
I estimate how holding a part-time political office affect income
and civil career of Danish local councilors. Concerning the latter, I
specifically investigate what being a local councilor do to the
councilors labour supply and probability of being promoted in their
outside job.

Policy Motivation and Political Selection: Does Policy
Discretion Retain Politicians?
I estimate how increased policy discretion in office affect whether
incumbents’ rerun and freshmen’s decide to run and who eventually win.
Thus, I estimate how policy discretion can be seen as a motivational
factor that change the supply of political candidates and change the
composition of the political class.

articles.title: Teaching
articles.contents:
Courses taught
Public Policy, Department of Political Science,
University of Copenhagen, Spring 2020, 2021, 2022
Cohort lecturing appr. 200 undergraduate students three weeks in a
row on topics like political rent-seeking, regulatory capture and
blame-avoidance.

Methods 3, Department of Political Science,
University of Copenhagen, Spring 2020 and 2021
Taught classes of appr. 35 undergraduate students on topics like
experimental designs, quasi-experimental designs and panel data
estimation.

Methods 1, Department of Political Science,
University of Copenhagen, Spring 2018
Taught a weekly class of appr. 35 undergraduate students, carried
out sections and workshops in applied methods and statistics.

Bachelor Thesis Methods Sessions, Department of
Political Science, University of Copenhagen, Spring 2018
Helped students with methodological and statistical concerns in
their bachelor theses throughout the semester.

Short courses/workshops
Quasi-experimental analyses in R, Department of
Psychology, University of Cambridge, May 2021
2 hour tutorial session for PhD students about regression
discontinuity designs and difference-in-differences designs and how to
implement them in R.
